title.value: ProtST: Multi-Modality Learning of Protein Sequences and Biomedical Texts
title.justification: The title of the paper is mentioned at the top of the document.
title.quote: ProtST: Multi-Modality Learning of Protein Sequences and Biomedical Texts

extractions.description: The paper presents ProtST, a framework aimed at enhancing Protein Sequence pre-training and understanding by incorporating biomedical texts. It introduces the ProtDescribe dataset, which pairs protein sequences with textual property descriptions, and proposes three types of tasks for pre-training: unimodal mask prediction, multimodal representation alignment, and multimodal mask prediction.

type.justification: The paper involves experiments and evaluations of the proposed ProtST framework using various protein-related tasks and benchmarks.
type.quote: We investigate the PLMs trained under ProtST by representation learning and zero-shot prediction.

name.justification: The paper focuses on the application of deep learning to protein sequences and biomedical texts, which falls under bioinformatics.
name.quote: Proteins serve as the mainstay governing diverse biological processes and life itself, inducing important applications in drug discovery and healthcare.

name.justification: The incorporation of biomedical texts into protein sequence representation learning involves Natural Language Processing techniques.
name.quote: Compared to the texts from general domains like newswire and Web, biomedical texts differ a lot in terms of vocabulary and expressions.

name.justification: The work involves computational methods to understand and predict biological properties and functions of proteins.
name.quote: Based on this dataset, we propose the ProtST framework to enhance protein sequence pre-training and understanding by biomedical texts.

name.justification: ProtST is the main model proposed in the paper for the purpose of enhancing protein sequence pre-training and understanding through the use of biomedical texts.
name.quote: Based on this dataset, we propose the ProtST framework to enhance protein sequence pre-training and understanding by biomedical texts.

is_contributed.justification: ProtST is introduced as a new model in this paper.
is_contributed.quote: we propose the ProtST framework to enhance protein sequence pre-training and understanding by biomedical texts.

is_executed.justification: The ProtST model was executed using computational resources, specifically GPUs, for training and evaluation.
is_executed.quote: Training Configurations: An Adam optimizer (Kingma & Ba, 2014) (learning rate: 1.0 × 10−5 , weight decay: 0) is used to train the whole model for 20 epochs on 4 Tesla V100 GPUs.

is_compared.justification: ProtST is compared to other existing models including OntoProtein, ProtBert, ESM-1b, and ESM-2 across various benchmarks.
is_compared.quote: We compare the proposed ProtST-ESM-1b with four performant PLMs, i.e., ESM-1b (Rives et al., 2021), ESM-1v (Meier et al., 2021), Tranception L (w/o retrieval) (Notin et al., 2022) and Progen2 XL (Nijkamp et al., 2022).

referenced_paper_title.justification: ProtST is the primary contribution of this paper, hence it is not referenced from another paper.

name.justification: ProtBert is used as one of the baseline models for comparison and as part of the larger ProtST framework.
name.quote: In this work, we select three state-of-the-art PLMs, ProtBert (Elnaggar et al., 2020), ESM-1b (Rives et al., 2021) and ESM-2 (Lin et al., 2022), as baselines and seek to enhance their representation power by modeling biomedical texts at the same time as protein sequence modeling.

is_contributed.justification: ProtBert is an existing model referenced in the paper.
is_contributed.quote: In this work, we select three state-of-the-art PLMs, ProtBert (Elnaggar et al., 2020), ESM-1b (Rives et al., 2021) and ESM-2 (Lin et al., 2022), as baselines.

is_executed.justification: ProtBert was executed as part of the experiments conducted in the paper.
is_executed.quote: In this work, we select three state-of-the-art PLMs, ProtBert (Elnaggar et al., 2020), ESM-1b (Rives et al., 2021) and ESM-2 (Lin et al., 2022), as baselines and seek to enhance their representation power by modeling biomedical texts at the same time as protein sequence modeling.

is_compared.justification: ProtBert serves as a baseline model against which the performance of the ProtST-enhanced models is compared.
is_compared.quote: We compare the proposed ProtST-ESM-1b with four performant PLMs, i.e., ESM-1b (Rives et al., 2021), ESM-1v (Meier et al., 2021), Tranception L (w/o retrieval) (Notin et al., 2022), and Progen2 XL (Nijkamp et al., 2022).

referenced_paper_title.value: Language models of protein sequences at the scale of evolution enable accurate structure prediction
referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper title is provided in the context of introducing ESM-2.

name.justification: PubMedBERT is a biomedical language model employed by the ProtST framework to represent the biomedical text descriptions of proteins.
name.quote: In this work, we employ a performant biomedical language model, PubMedBERT (Gu et al., 2021), to represent the biomedical text descriptions of proteins.

is_contributed.justification: PubMedBERT is an existing model referenced in the paper.
is_contributed.quote: In this work, we employ a performant biomedical language model, PubMedBERT (Gu et al., 2021), to represent the biomedical text descriptions of proteins.

is_executed.justification: PubMedBERT was executed as part of the ProtST framework to process the biomedical text descriptions.
is_executed.quote: To start this process with decent representations of protein sequences and biomedical texts, we use pre-trained PLM (i.e., ProtBert (Elnaggar et al., 2020), ESM-1b (Rives et al., 2021) or ESM-2 (Lin et al., 2022)) and pre-trained BLM (i.e., PubMedBERT (Gu et al., 2021)) for initialization.

is_compared.justification: PubMedBERT is not directly compared to other models in terms of performance; it is used within the ProtST framework.

referenced_paper_title.value: Domain-specific language model pretraining for biomedical natural language processing
referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper title is provided in the context of introducing PubMedBERT.

name.justification: The ProtDescribe dataset is introduced in this paper as a paired dataset of protein sequences and textual property descriptions.
name.quote: we first build the ProtDescribe dataset to augment protein sequences with text descriptions of their functions and other important properties.

referenced_paper_title.justification: ProtDescribe is contributed in this paper and not referenced from another paper.

name.justification: Swiss-Prot is referenced as the source of high-quality protein annotations used to construct the ProtDescribe dataset.
name.quote: We resort to the Swiss-Prot database (Bairoch & Apweiler, 2000) for high-quality protein annotations.

referenced_paper_title.value: The Swiss-Prot protein sequence database and its supplement TrEMBL in 2000
referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper title is provided in the context of mentioning the source of protein annotations.
